Idiom (Grenadian Creole French): Chyen ka wouklé koté i jwenn zo
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause with progressive aspect marker 'ka'
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: People tend to return to where they find benefit or comfort
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People return to what benefits them
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from observation of dogs returning to familiar places for bones; common rural metaphor
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Grenadian C: ʃjɛ̃ ka wukle kote i ʒwɛn zo
First Example Sentence: I pa bizwen mandé, chyen ka wouklé koté i jwenn zo.
Second Example Sentence: Tout moun sav, chyen toujou ka wouklé koté i jwenn zo.
Third Example Sentence: Li ja pati, mé i kay tounen paski chyen ka wouklé koté i jwenn zo.

Idiom (Grenadian Creole French): Kòk ki chanté bonè, ka manjé dan sò
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed relative clause with aspectual emphasis
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Those who speak too early often face the consequences
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Agricultural proverb rooted in early-morning rooster behavior
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Grenadian C: kɔk ki ʃɑ̃te bɔnɛ ka mɑ̃ʒe dɑ̃ sɔ

Second Example Sentence: Pa palé two vit, paske kòk ki chanté bonè ka manjé dan sò.
Third Example Sentence: I di bagay-la two bonè, e sa viré kont li.

Third Example Sentence: Bon zèv toujou tounen, kon lapòt ou ouvè pou lòt.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Things take time; patience brings justice
